course_title: Biology for Health Sciences Part B

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and explain the structure and function of the cardiovascular, respiratory, digestive, renal, and integumentary systems
Identify and explain the structure and function of the reproductive system and the principles of human development
Describe how homeostatic mechanisms regulate the function of the human body through multiple systems
Differentiate between innate and acquired immunity, and describe the role of immunology in medicine
Explain the structure and function of the components of microbial cells and how pathogenic microbes cause disease
Display sound scientific reasoning in the context of practical sessions in human anatomy, human physiology, immunology and microbiology
Apply critical thinking and reasoning skills to understand and analyse the interconnectedness and interdependencies of various biological systems studied to date.
Effectively communicate complex anatomical and physiological concepts orally and/or in written form to various audiences.

assessments.weighting: <dd>10% (To achieve 10%, you must complete 8 of the 11 workshop activities). </dd>
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
We will offer eleven (11) content-specific workshops throughout the semester to enhance your understanding of the course material. You must complete a specific assessment activity in each workshop and submit it before you leave the workshop. You will earn 10% toward your course grade if you complete and submit at least eight (8) of these eleven (11) activities. If you complete fewer than eight (8) activities, you will receive 0%.

More details will be provided during class and available on the Course Blackboard page.

What if I am unable to attend all eight (8)? We have given you ample notice to manage your time and attend these classes. However, if you cannot attend due to illness or other exceptional circumstances, please contact your Course Coordinator to discuss your options.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submissions must be completed in-class during workshops.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

During scheduled class. The week 2, 5, and 11 quizzes will occur in your scheduled practical classes. Please check your timetable to confirm the dates and times.
assessments.task_description:
Active contribution to your practical classes is a requirement of BIOM1071. During your practical classes, you will receive a quiz covering key concepts relating to the respective module content and practical class activities. This quiz will consist of multiple-choice questions and a short answer question.

Please be aware that the quiz in week 11 will include questions covering the practical sessions from both week 10 and week 11, as these sessions are connected in a series.

Absence from a Practical Session

You are expected to attend 100% of your practical classes throughout the semester.

However, if you cannot attend your practical class, you must apply for a deferral through my.UQ, with appropriate documentation. If approved, an alternate time to complete the quiz in-person will be arranged.

More details will be provided during class and available on the Course Blackboard page. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You will complete this quiz in person, on paper.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The examination will cover the content related to Modules 1, 2, and 3, including lectures, prescribed readings, videos, and assessment tasks. This exam will enable you to demonstrate the scope and depth of your learning in areas relevant to the respiratory, cardiovascular and reproductive systems. The mid-semester exam will consist of multiple-choice, short-answer and interactive questions. All multiple-choice questions will be in "best of 5" format, i.e. selecting the best answer from 5 alternatives. 

More details of the examination format will be provided during the semester.

The exam will be a closed-book invigilated exam on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students must bring a laptop that meets the device requirements for Inspera to the exam. It is essential to verify before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website, "Get familiar with Inspera," provides the latest information for students on using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.

Please have your UQ student ID card available for all exams.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The examination will cover the content related to Modules 4, 5, 6 and 7, including lectures, prescribed readings, videos and assessment tasks. The exam will also assess the content of all practicals. This exam will enable you to demonstrate the scope and depth of your learning in areas relevant to the digestive and renal systems, microbiology, and immunology. The end-of-semester exam will consist of multiple-choice, short-answer and interactive questions. All multiple-choice questions will be in "best of 5" format, i.e. selecting the best answer from 5 alternatives. 

More details of the examination format will be provided during the semester.

The exam will be a closed-book invigilated exam on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students must bring a laptop that meets the device requirements for Inspera to the exam. It is essential to verify before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website, "Get familiar with Inspera," provides the latest information for students on using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.

Please have your UQ student ID card available for all exams.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 2(28 Jul - 10 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Respiratory System

- Respiratory system, Dr Danielle Burgess (5 lecture hours). In this module, you will learn about the anatomy and physiology of the respiratory system and learn what differentiates the upper and the lower regions. You will learn about how the components of the thoracic cavity work in conjunction with various pressures to facilitate inspiration and expiration, and then how the body maintains oxygen and carbon dioxide homeostasis. You will learn how gas exchange occurs and the importance of this within the body. Finally, you will have a brief overview of measuring respiratory function, which will be consolidated in practical classes.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture series - Respiratory System - Respiratory system, Dr Danielle Burgess (5 lecture hours). In this module, you will learn about the anatomy and physiology of the respiratory system and learn what differentiates the upper and the lower regions. You will learn about how the components of the thoracic cavity work in conjunction with various pressures to facilitate inspiration and expiration, and then how the body maintains oxygen and carbon dioxide homeostasis. You will learn how gas exchange occurs and the importance of this within the body. Finally, you will have a brief overview of measuring respiratory function, which will be consolidated in practical classes.

Physiology Practical Series

- Week 3 (8th August): Spirometry


*Check your timetable for your group's start time.

Readings/Ref: Practicals; PPE

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(04 Aug - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Workshops

Starting from week 2, there will be eleven weeks of workshops held throughout the semester. These workshops will enable you to collaborate with peers and academic staff to consolidate the knowledge gained in lectures and deepen your understanding of more complex concepts.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Workshops Starting from week 2, there will be eleven weeks of workshops held throughout the semester. These workshops will enable you to collaborate with peers and academic staff to consolidate the knowledge gained in lectures and deepen your understanding of more complex concepts.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 3 To Week 4(11 Aug - 24 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Cardiovascular System

- Cardiovascular system, Dr Niwanthi Rajapakse (5 lecture hours). In this module, you will explore the Anatomy and Physiology of the cardiovascular system and the blood. You will learn the specific regions of the heart and the blood vessels, and how each region contributes to blood flow. You will learn about the cardiac cycle, cardiac output and the various factors that impact mean arterial pressure. Finally, you will learn about the electrical properties of the heart.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture series - Cardiovascular System - Cardiovascular system, Dr Niwanthi Rajapakse (5 lecture hours). In this module, you will explore the Anatomy and Physiology of the cardiovascular system and the blood. You will learn the specific regions of the heart and the blood vessels, and how each region contributes to blood flow. You will learn about the cardiac cycle, cardiac output and the various factors that impact mean arterial pressure. Finally, you will learn about the electrical properties of the heart.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 6(18 Aug - 07 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Reproductive System

- Reproduction, Dr Lisa Akison (6 lecture hours). In this module, you will learn the anatomy and the physiology of the male and female reproductive tracts, the fertilisation process and how a new human develops. You will also learn key information on the clinical aspects of reproduction.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture series - Reproductive System - Reproduction, Dr Lisa Akison (6 lecture hours). In this module, you will learn the anatomy and the physiology of the male and female reproductive tracts, the fertilisation process and how a new human develops. You will also learn key information on the clinical aspects of reproduction.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 8(18 Aug - 21 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Anatomy Practical Series

Starting in week 3, there will be two 2-hour anatomy-based practicals in the Gross Anatomy Facility (GAF):


- Week 4 (20th Aug): Introduction & Cardiorespiratory anatomy

- Week 8 (17th Sept): GIT, renal & reproductive anatomy


*Check your timetable for your group's start time

Readings/Ref: Textbook; Practicals; PPE; OnlineAnatTrain; Face2Face; AnatomyAct; CrimCode; UQAnatGovern; AnatCode


Learning outcomes: L03, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 6 To Week 8(01 Sep - 21 Sep)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Digestive & Renal system

- Digestive & Renal system, Dr Judit Kibedi (6 lecture hours). In this module, you will be learning the anatomy and physiology of the digestive and renal systems. You will learn how the different components regulate nutrients and wastes within the body. You will learn the regions of the nephron, the key cells within the kidneys, and how they work to absorb and secrete to ensure the body maintains homeostasis.

  • Please note that the lecture on 9 September will be provided online, rather than in person. More details will be provided through Annoucements on Blackboard.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L07, L08

You will learn the regions of the nephron, the key cells within the kidneys, and how they work to absorb and secrete to ensure the body maintains homeostasis. Please note that the lecture on 9 September will be provided online, rather than in person. More details will be provided through Annoucements on Blackboard.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 11(22 Sep - 19 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Microbiology

Microbiology, Dr Steven Hancock (5 lecture hours).

In this module, you will learn key microbiology topics, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites. You will learn which of these are medically relevant and their associated infections. You will learn about the evolution of infection and treatment processes.

Readings/Ref: Textbook; Textbook; Mastering A&P



Learning outcomes: L03, L05, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 10 To Week 11(06 Oct - 19 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Microbiology & Immunology Practical Series

During weeks 10 (8th or 9th Oct) & 11 (15th or 16th Oct), there will be two 3-hour microbiology/bacteriology practicals, held in the Molecular Biosciences laboratories. Please ensure you check your timetable for your group's start day and time.


Learning outcomes: L03, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 13(13 Oct - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series - Immunology

Immunology, Professor Kate Stacey (6 lecture hours).

In this module, you will learn about the different types of immunity, including innate immunity and acquired immunity. You will learn about Immunology in Medicine and the mechanisms and importance of vaccines.

Readings/Ref: Textbook; Textbook; Mastering A&P


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L06, L07, L08
